Name: Physics of the Future: How Science Will Shape Human Destiny and Our Daily Lives by the Year 2100

ReviewList.Text: In "Physics of the Future," Michio Kaku provides us with glimpses of the near and long futures with a simplistic, perhaps overly simplistic, writing style.  It is, as is usual coming from the mind of a scientist, an extremely optimistic and glowing portrait of humanity's inevitable march of technological progress, with very little concern or thought put into the wild contradictions of modernity, how the forces of free market capitalism, democracy, environmental degradation, etc. will play out.  Scientists do not live in a bubble, and if the world is at war or swept up by revolution then science cannot function.  I think there's equal chance that humanity will be living in the aftermath of a nuclear apocalypse 100 years from now as it will be living in technological splendor.

Michio Kaku does a great job painting his visions on paper with this book. He makes it very easy for anyone to visualize exactly what he is thinking and the best part is his constant attempt at witty humor. i would recomend this book for the non-scholar looking to learn a little more about the possibilities of modern science.

Overall, this book has some good insight into what the future might be.  Unfortunately, the book could have been about one-third shorter if all the redundancies had been removed.  If you want to get a good overview of the entire book, simply read the last chapter.  I checked this book out of the library, and I sure am glad that I didn't pay for it.

I just couldn't believe how simplistic the writing was, uninventive writing, starts off every chapter with the same boring mythology analogy. Maby it was just me, but I already knew about a lot of the technologies he was talking about. however a fresh  explanation wouldnt have hurt, how it works and why, the explanations were extremely basic and almost written for someone who had  never heard of something like augmented reality or life extension before, you could find more interesting tidbits just by going to Wikipedia. There was not enough innovative thinking about the far far future, which is what I was expecting, any guesses were boring and bland and not at all indicative of how superbly innovative humanity can be.  The only thing I really enjoyed was the explanations on levels of civilizations, but I already had seen that on a discovery channel interview with him, which is what made me buy the book. Perhaps the book just wasnt for me.

First off, I'm a huge fan of Michio's, and the only reason I gave this book a 4 instead of a 5 is because it's not Michio's best book, but it's still an excellent book. With that being said, if it was written by anyone else, it would be a 5. The book is extremely interesting and for those of us with imaginations who really wonder what technologies will be around in 90 years, this is the definitive book. Well done Mr. Kaku.

Anyone familiar with Michio Kaku's television series "Physics of the Impossible", or the book for that matter, might find his recent material getting a little repetitive as far as what the future holds. I feel like this book pretty much details much of the material covered in "Physics of the Impossible", and his show on the Discovery Science channel of the same title. Don't get me wrong, the book would have been a complete success if it wasn't for the fact that we've sorta heard it all before from him. I really wish he would pick a new subject to cover in his next book, or at least give us something new to ponder about the future of technology and physics. I personally think Dr. Kaku, along with Neil DeGrasse Tyson, Brian Cox, Brian Greene and Lawrence Krauss are among the best communicators of modern physics that we have available today, Michio Kaku being the better of all in my opinion. I've been both a fan and a follower since the fist time I saw him speak in his simple, "Carl Sagan like" tone. I think he has a natural gift of relating otherwise uncomprehendable subjects to the masses in a way we can all understand, which is why I give this book 4 stars. It's a really good book that will certainly make you stop and think, and definately has that page turning quality. I just think it would be really hard for Dr. Kaku to match the quality of his ealier book "Hyperspace".. That was the book that opened my mind to physics and the magic of science. Sometimes, we humans tend to outdue our own selves and make it hard to match what preceded our earlier accomplishments. I will always be a fan, but surprise us with something completely unconventional for a change!!

Super topic and well written. A must read for anyone thinking about where our lives might be headed and why. E.G. in 1914, who could have imagined that I would be texting a response to a question asked by a virtual retailer, about a book ordered on a personal computer, via the internet, delivered to my door, in two days, via airplane and truck, on a wireless telepone.

Prof. Kaku is not only a first rate physist, he's also a very good writer.  This is an interesting topic, and his glances back at history make the book very enjoyable.  I think many of the items of the future will come before his prediction, mainly because in the global economy there are more folks doing grand things other that the USA. It's a book worth reading.

Michio Kaku scores again with another great book. His vision of the future makes me want to live long enough to see it, and that's coming from a woman who is somewhat jaded to this life. Very interesting!

I strongly recommend this book as an update of what universities, labs and institutions, all over the world, are working on in many different fields. The information sources are connoted researches and Nobel laureates.

I love it - this book is great. Describes very possible technologies that are going to happen in the nearest future. Good to read it and get some inspirations. I bought first some older book of Michio Kaku and it was ok but a little bit expired already. this one is on time and still refers to realistic technologies.
I'm a layman on this subject, and this book was informative and easy to understand for people like me. Kaku will often make pop culture references so that it is also very fun to read.

I can't say for sure if I am going to enjoy this by the end of the book, but so far its ok. I have read 70 some pages into it, and I can say that its interesting yes, but I am pretty sure that I of all people could do a better job writing about some of the ideas discussed here. It seems to be talking about one idea in computer science, and then jumps to some kind of screen on a wall, instead of ideas of how silicon will eventually disappear.... etc. But I don't hate it near enough to put it down, because I want to have some sort of way of knowing what our world will look like in the future. The ultimate question for anyone: What will the world be when I am long gone?! Well, I want to have some sort of idea, so I know what I am missing out on! So in general, I am still glad I bought it. Oh, and the binding is pretty cheap and come further into some pages from the center than others...

I cannot find other words but to call it light, it has the quality content of a large Time magazine article, not bad for a MAGAZINE but a lot to be desired for a book. I do read Wired, Time, etc, and most of the info you read here you already know if you read any of those magazines, I'm disapointed.

This book was highly enjoyable. Michio Kaku not only provides the reader with substantial evidentiary support to his predictions of the future, but he does it in a fashion that enables individuals to share his personal experiences. For those of you who are fond of futuristic ideology, this book is highly recommended. Kaku provides interesting artistic depictions of futuristic commodities and simplistically describes the intricate physical laws of the universe, which enables readers of all scientific backgrounds to easily decipher the information provided. Essentially, what makes the book even more intriguing is how he includes interviews of over 200 scientists that all specialize in different fields. This enables the reader to have a broader perspective, while also being exposed to Kaku’s complex understanding of physics and Moore’s Law. I find his theories interesting on nanotechnology, artificial intelligence and the architectural reconstruction of the next millennium. In conclusion, his overall creative yet methodical approach to these intricate concepts makes this book all of the more pleasurable to read.

By the year 2100 the application of gene therapy, augmented reality and programmable matter will be as ubiquitous as the PC is today. Renowned physicist Michio Kaku explains these predictions and many more in Physics of the Future. I am not surprised by Kaku's discussion of internet-ready contact lenses, nanotechnology or even the inevitable collapse of Moore's Law. His prognostications regarding robotics and space travel, on the other hand, are insightful as they strip away the hype created by popular culture and lay bare the stark reality. Although not a central theme, Kaku also argues the pivotal role of science and technology in world economic development and often alludes to a bright future for careers that involve a high level of pattern recognition such as artists, lawyers and software engineers. The book is split into 8 chapters, each following a similar structure that outline the near future, midcentury and far future potential of various technological advances. I found the repetition of this chapter structure tiresome and expect the book would be far more enjoyable if read in separate sittings.

Professor Kaku is generally regarded as the modern Einstein since he is he leading proponent of String Theory, the theory which attempts to produce "The Theory of Everything"  by linking up the Theory of Relativity and Quantum Mechanics.  One would think a brain box like that could bore for America at the Olympics, but not Kaku.  He has a disarming way of explaining difficult concepts in a reachable and readable way that engages even those to whom mathematics is little more than a nightmare.  His predictions for the future of science in many fields are wonderfully reassuring and promise a bright future for a mankind that learns to use these technologies for the benefit of all.  I sometimes fell that he "knows more than he is telling" particularly in the area of trans-luminal flight and the application now of new energy sources, but since all research is funded by BigOil and BigPharma, University Boffins have to toe the line if they are not to choke off the source of their research money.  The Book is thoroughly enjoyable and must for anyone needing to know where we are going.

Michio Kaku is the lay reader's dream - an accomplished scientist who communicates intricate concepts in a way anyone can comprehend. In his book, Kaku offers a deeply researched study of the technologies that will create society's future. He tackles everything from computer screens on contact lenses to magnetic levitation, artificial intelligence and nanotechnology. To keep his treatise reader-friendly, he brings in examples from Greek mythology, Star Trek and the Terminator movies. At times Kaku seems a bit too optimistic about the gee-whiz direction of the world, which he believes eventually will be free of cancer, car crashes and the ravages of aging. But he does temper some of his predictions: He points out the limits of stem cells and artificial intelligence, and he notes the dangers of global warming. getAbstract recommends his analysis to readers seeking an erudite but easy-to-digest survey of the innovations shaping the future.

The latest book by renowned theoretical physicist Michio Kaku is perhaps his most ambitious project yet. In "Physics of the Future: How Science Will Shape Human Destiny & Our Daily Lives by the Year 2100", he examines in depth what he believes will happen to everything in our world from medicine to computing to weather to space travel in the 21st century. What's unique about this book is that the predictions in this book aren't so far fetched since he's spoken with hundreds of scientists who are on the cutting edge of discovery right now & has witnessed some of these potential discoveries on his own. It's arranged in such a way that while there is a progression necessary in the book to follow things, the science is simplied to a point where the average reader isn't overwhelmed by the details. This is very much a fun book to enjoy for anyone who wants a vision of where we might be by the dawn of the 22nd century.

My son aspires to be an astrophysicist in exotic propulsion systems. I'm just a regular Mom, not anywhere near as brainy as my son whom I purchased the book for as a reward for passing a very, very difficult exam in the Air Force.  As smart as he is, he doesn't like reading much but the day he got this book in the mail he was 1/3rd of the way through it by the time I called him to see if he'd gotten it yet lol.  This fact based book was so enjoyable to him, that my kid was immediately inspired by Michio Kaku to go and purchase a pair of rare earth magnets through Amazon to resume an experiment he'd been working on before he left for the AF.  [I didn't even know you could get that kind of thing from Amazon but I'm starting to see that you can buy just about anything through Amazon.]  We always enjoyed watching the show hosted by Michio Kaku, Sci-Fi Channel's "Explorations".

I am just beginning what appears to be a fascinating read by the eminent Professor Kaku.  I am not a scientist, merely a retired attorney with a bachelor's degree in history. I do take exception, however, with his statement that U.S. Commissioner of Patents Charles H. Duell said, in 1899, that everything had could be invented had already been invented.  This attribution has been debunked.  Rather, in 1902, Duell stated:" In my opinion, all previous advances in the various lines of invention will appear totally insignificant when compared with those which the present century will witness. I almost wish that I might live my life over again to see the wonders which are at the threshold."  Now, while this has no bearing on the science Dr. Kaku presents, it shows a touch of carelessness which could have been easily eliminated with a bit of fact checking.

I'm a fan of Michio Kaku so this is going to be a biased review. While I've seen him in numerous television shows and interviews this is the first book of his that I have read. I loved it. He makes it so the lay man can understand physics concepts, but he doesn't "dumb it down" so much that it's boring. It's not purely a physics book either. He talks about current situations, like the energy crisis and going green and suggest future situations where we can improve or better ourselves. There are some grim scenarios but overall it's a positive view of the future. That's why I guess I like the book so much. I loved to read up on the latest futurist, Ray Kurzweil, etc. It's one of my favorite reads so when I found out Michio had written a futurist book; I had to check it out. It's been difficult to put down. I definitely plan on reading more of his books.

This was a great read for me - mainly because it was fun way to learn about physics and all the incredible technology and advancements that are on the horizon for humanity. Michio Kaku combines hard science with storytelling and even some classic mythology to create a nice blend of educational material that is also entertaining at the same time. I never felt bogged down by concepts that were too complex to explain, and many times I would stop and contemplate how the future would look when reading some of his concepts and predictions. For those who have only been exposed to Michio through his many tv appearances and would like to get more of his unique offerings - this book is a great way to get more insight from him and his incredible mind. Not only will you learn a few things, you will be entertained along the way.

This book did not disappoint! The author's stories of the astounding scientific possibilities for mankind in the next 100 years make this book both exciting and terrifying, as he has a powerful ability to make complicated academic theories readable and relevant to everyone. However, this isn't just a thriller to be read through quickly, as it takes awhile to digest each topic. I would recommend the book to any serious individual who cares about the planet and future generations; I believe they would find it thought-provoking and something they would re-read for many years. Moreover, young people planning their futures and seeking a career that will stay relevant and make a positive impact on the world would do well to use it as a guidebook.

Michio Kaku has taken a rather positive view of the future.  He believes that science will be able to solve many of the problems that we face on earth today.  He has carefully crafted a view and timeline of the future based on the realities of the here and now.  I do think his optimism about mankind is a bit strong.  Many assumptions he has made are based on people acting rationally.  As we have seen all too often, such is not always the case.  He also minimizes the impact a global calamity could have on the progression of mankind. While I have these objections to his projected potential reality, the book is a very interesting read.  He has a knack of taking extremely complex topics and making them comprehensible to the average reader.

Machio Kaku makes us dream wide-eyed with his forecast of the fantastic wonders of technology he claims will be available before this century is out:  unlimited energy, space elevators, very long lives, freedom from disease, a brave new world, etc.  The culmination is his last chapter, "A day in the life in 2100", which rivals the best and most ambitious science-fiction description of life in the future.  But is he being a tad optimistic?  I don't know.  The Internet, the GPS, the cell phone, were not predicted by the futurists of decades past.  As his fellow futurist J. B. S. Haldane said in the 1920s, "The world is not only stranger than we imagine, it is stranger than we CAN imagine."

This book was so amazing to read it was almost impossible to put down. The ideas have a strong foundation in science but at the same time are very straight forward to understand even if you don't know scientific concepts. Michio Kaku is a fantastic author and makes complex science very easy to understand and a delight to read. I would recommend this book to anyone who is curious about the future, and even if you're not this book will make you think twice about the future. I'm much more optimistic about the future now and very excited to be alive to experience it!

I always enjoy reading and watching Michio Kaku. He's a brilliant man. This book was informative and uses jargon most people will understand. His batting average for predicting the future will stand the test of time. I only wish he and his contemporaries would dial back the debatable climate change-global warming-global cooling-global disaster narrative. Despite his lip service to capitalism and his underlying bias to government being the answer to many of society's ills, I'll still sift through Michio Kaku's future books because he is that good.

I picked this up at the air port before a cross-country flight and had it finished a day later.  Kaku takes complex theories from the real of physics and other fields and puts them into words that just about anyone could understand while adding in references we all should be pretty familiar with.  The specific things he talks on are fascinating in my eyes and lay out (both in his treatment of the past, present as well as the future) how just about any idea can become reality somehow given enough time (and funding).  I can't recommend this enough.

In my opinion, the only area where the book fails spectacularly is in the area of economics. The battle between Adam Smith's 'invisible hand' and Garrett Hardin's 'tragedy of the commons' will occupy us for the next 100 years and beyond, yet like so many wishful thinkers the author doesn't even the acknowledge the existence of a competing memeplex to Smith's 'unlimited personal greed best serves the greater good'. Despite this flaw, I don't regret the time I spent reading this book.

Michio Kaku's book educates and entertains. It has stirred in me an even deeper commitment toward making choices in my life that are better for the future of the planet. His book has made me feel profoundly part of the future. Not only is it science that will shape the forthcoming years, but our choices as individuals. A must read for anyone interested in getting broad insight on our human and planetary situation, the difficulties and wonders that are just around the corner.

This book is really interesting. I like that the author really shows the progression from today's technology to both the near and distant future. Michio Kaku supports all of his descriptions with examples of scientific experiments and trials that are going on right now. He has personally tested many of these awesome inventions. It makes me so excited to think about how technology will change and improve our lives in just the rest of my own lifetime.

This was a pretty fascinating read with a lot packed into it. Some of his predictions are actually a bit nerve racking,  but I suppose that is the fear of the unknown. Most of the book I think isn't too far fetched to envision,  but I do wonder about his predictions regarding politics. He covers many aspects of technology, medicine, politics, science, and pop culture. Definitely would recommend the book. It is a long, but very interesting read.

Although I have enjoyed Dr. Kaku and his comments on science on TV, I have never read any of his books.  He has a enjoyable writing style the clearly delineates and defines scientific terms and concepts for this non-scientist.  He provides three time frame scenarios (today-2030, 2030-2070 and 2070-2100) and bases his comments on main stream science.  Although the subjects are explored in depth, the book is a very easy and enjoyable read.

Found myself feeling jealous of my unborn great grandchild as I image the future. Loved Michio Kaku's book and his attention to grounded actual scientific research rather than science fiction. Reinforcing that our future as human being and as a planet resides with inventive scientists and forward-thinking investment. Physics of the Future seems to me a much more productive conversation for our current political narrative.

Received this book has a gift, probably would of skipped it otherwise.  Michio is one of many popularizers of science, and this book is of that trend.  Written for general audiences, light on scientific theory going quickly into sci-fi speculation.  Some of the topics are old and are repeated here again, for instance the dream of fusion reactors and robots being our personal servants.  We've heard this for the past thirty or more years and it still seems a long way off.  With that in mind it's hard not to be skeptical of his other predictions, programmable matter, self replicating robots and so on.  Still, I did enjoy his overview of emerging technologies and their potential for changing society.

I love this book. It's worth reading several times out of sheer excitement for the future. It gives a far better hope for the future of the human species than any religious superstition. Rather than being based on wishful thinking or nonsense, it's based on Science! Seeing as how I am in my mid-30's I will see some of this come to life! It also gives me some self gratification on my choice to enter the IT field.

Awesome read. It's a realistic view of the future, broken down into what's currently going on, what's right around the corner and what will be seen a few years off. This book wasn't written long ago and I have already notices several things available to the average person now that he proposes in this book. If you are curious of what the future will be like, without the unrealistic fantasy, this is a great book.

This is the second book by Michio Kaku that I've read, the first being Physics of the Impossible.  While this is an excellent read, it's not so much "physics" of the future as it is "science" in general of the future.  Biochemistry, renewable energy, etc. are topics covered.  While there is a bit of physics in regards to space travel, it's not as physics centered as Physics of the Impossible.

A most interesting read about what to expect in the future. To my surprise, some of the predicitions are already in motion, such as, driverless cars. If you love science this book is must reading. The subject is very well documented and all of his ideas are consistent with ongoing research. I admit some of the material was over my head. But I understand what his conculsions are and value his insights.

A brilliant book by the brilliant Dr. Michio Kaku in which he interviews hundreds of the top scientists in the field and in the laboratory to predict accurately based on this research what will happen in the years 2030, 2070, and 2100 based on what is taking place in research today. A brilliant mind pondering book. I highly recommend it to everyone.
This book is a nice look at the future of mankind and his advances in technology.
I expect more than a little of what Kaku envisions will happen even more quickly than he's anticipated--time will tell!
Excellent narrative by Dr.  Kaku. Must read for all who love science. Lets  you know the intricate details of our future.

It raise a very good question: would technology be allow to advance for a few more millennia or would humans deplete the earth to the point of inhabitable and are forced to abandon it before there is a means to leave the earth? Don't sink this boat before we find another one that is habitable and better!
This was an easy read that linked the current and expected future state of science to the continuation of life on earth.
Very good considerations for those things that will affect us near term what we and our children can plan for in the future.
Captivating book.I enjoyed every bit of it..Michio Kaku writes in a reader friendly manner about a complicated group of subjects.

I watch a lot of science shows and Michio is one of my favorites.  As McCoy once said to Spock "He means that he feels safer about your guesses than most other people's facts".  That is how I feel about Michio's speculations.  He tells it like it may very well become.  I now feel like I have a decent idea of what life will be like in 2100.

I sometimes watch this guy talk and i can think he is crazy. but reading this book he has done his homework and the reader would have a hard time saying "nope that wont happen". i think hes shooting to be a modern Jules Verne in some way.
Not a literary masterpiece but somewhat refreshing to read something positive about the possible future of the human race. Well worth the read.

I love learning about possibilities.  This book explains science in a way that makes sense to the non doctorate yet intelligent, curious individual.  Moreover, the references to verify what was said is also provide for further enlightenment.  But, this book gets five stars because it makes what could quickly be overwhelming into something that is both interesting and relevant.  We talk about many of the things discussed in this book.  Prof. Kaku brings relevance to those discussions by explaining what is possible now and in the future.  If you ever wonder about the direction computers, medical care, space travel, and robotics will take then this is the book to read.  You don't even need to be a geek!
Does a great job of covering a lot of different topics with good reasoning behind his predictions. He includes economics but I'm not sure how human greed will affect his view of the future.
A good sneak peek of the future, thought provoking and inspiring. Some of the timelines seem to be off, as some have already come to pass.
Michio Kaku explains things in a way a layperson can easily understand.  He left me very excited about the future.

I have bought and read all of Dr. Kaku's older books and found them to be absolutely fascinating. I have a post-secondary education and science background (although not in Physics) but the books were written at just the right level ... understandable for someone with a college or university level education. Now I can understand that to increase sales, he needed to write books which appeal to a wider audience, but as a result, he has and will lose the more educated audience that bought all of his original books. I certainly won't bother with his writings anymore ... perhaps my 12 year old son would be interested?

Excellent information!  Interesting!  Seems repetitive in the book, but still poses realistic and track able examples of changes we are facing.  Also, written a few years ago and, some predictions have already transpired.

I'm a massive Kaku fan and perhaps that is a bit of an issue, as a lot of the text I have read in this book is word for word from many of the videos and TV shows Kaku has appeared in. Still, loads of interesting guff to please techno geeks and nerds alike in this well written book that does a great job of catering to the lay person. Excellent read!
Great book. We'll written. Michio has a gift for explaining even the most complex of technologies so that a broad audience can interpret and understand what would otherwise be jargon.

I really enjoyed the ideas this book provides for the future of humanity. of course no one knows what will happen but it is always fun to theorize. I think Michio Kaku did an amazing job with these theories in this book.
Love the book, it is well told with good arguments!! It gives you a good sense of what is happening in science and what could become reality.
Good voice with very good articulation. Very very educative. It makes me appreciate the importance of science around me.....as well the arts.

Michio offers a look into various points in our future using generally accepted physics theories on how technology advances. Equally parts fascinating and upsetting, only because I would donate all of my internal organs just to see interstellar travel just once before I die, and he spells out reasons why it's very unrealistic for me to expect this in my lifetime. Problems like unsustainable population grown due to rapid advances in medical technology could've used a little more attention, but overall this was a really good read, and I would recommend it highly to anyone interested in this particular field
Excellent for anyone with or without a science background.  All you need is curiosity.  Good companion to his book Visions.

While the book did not blow me away, i found most of it interesting but not revolutionary in its thinking.  Most of the future seems linear from his book while we know it won't be.  Enjoyable read but..
Michio makes our somewhat questionable future sound a little less awful. I loved this book and I look forward to another.

I'm currently writing a YA book set in the future and this book gave me some ideas of what would be feasible or not in terms of science and technology. Besides that, it is a very interesting read, especially for anyone interested in how technology is evolving and changing our world. The author takes a pretty objective approach- in other words he is not gung ho about some advances or wickedly fearful of the future. He has a very practical approach to the future of science and it's effects on our society as a whole. His writing style is easy to read, not too complex for the non-science person. I've used it as a research book for building my futuristic world and for that it has been a great resource.
Quite well written covers a lot of developing areas in technology. Its more of an overview nothing to deep or detailed.
I like the classification for various degrees of mathematical expertise.  I supposedly have a minor in Maths, but stick with the simple explanation first time.  A steal when bought used.
very interesting reading about latest achievments in sciense,I like it.English is not  my native language but anyway,I fond of it

Kaku has always been great at exressing his enthusiasm for all things science and tech based. He explains everything in casual terms and talks about things that really are crazy to even consider possible let alone real. His books are always my morning reads while i still have some coffee left. Brings out the inner nerd

This book is very well written and obviously painstakingly put together. I would have given it 5 stars but there were some aspects of it that seemed to drift into conjecture rather than the science. While that is something that obviously has to be done when making  predictions it left it somewhat opinionated based on personal beliefs from the past that are not always based on fact. Highly recommended however.

This review is coming from someone that can't stand to read. I  can't put this book down its so intriguing. Every page is well thought out and I can't wait handling until I get his next book.  this is the best book I've ever read! I absolutely love it!!!
This book tells clearly about the human livings in the future. I think the governments of the countries should consider the possible technologies in the future in developing their strategies.

I couldn't put this book down and was able understand what he was telling me as a reader.  Michio Kau is able to describe incredible science and technology inventions/discoveries so that the average person can understand their potential advantages to the world as we know it. We are truly living in amazing times and there are some incredible minds doing incredible things.  I will reread this book many times.  It's my bible.

The author did a good job with this book.  More of a book with educated guesses than a book that you feel like you walked away with something having read it.  Well organized but a little bit repetitive. Easy to skim, tough to read.

This book is well written and easy to understand.  Dr. KAKU explains the possibilities of scientific research and development.  He also outlines how these developments will affect humanity future development.
I am still in the process of reading it, but the theories and facts that I have learned are awesome.

This book definitely opened my eyes. The information that Michio has given in this book you would think that he is in another world! This book has changed my life. I want to be on the forefront of this technology.

Very exciting .Very technical at times but it is glimpse of the future. Very well written. Am looking forward to seeing what will happen in the years to come.I have recommended this book to many people in the medical and scientific community.
The good think from michio is the way he write hard and complex material with soft style writing. You will hard to stop reading and more you read more you highlighted....
A very engaging read.  It's exciting to learn what my granddaughters will be experiencing long after I'm gone.  Michio Kaku writes in a way that the non-physicist can appreciate.

It's not a deep scientific text and of course it doesn't aim to cover the real physics behind every new discovery, but it is a good review of the technologies that are already changing our world. It reminded me of Carl Sagan's "science for everyone" works...

I'm old enough to remember the first TV in my family and my first transistor radio in the early to mid 1950's, and to see where we are today is eye opening. I believe that if we don't destroy ourselves my grandchildrens children will be able to travel freely about our solar system. Anybody can understand this book the way he explains it.
If you are into sci-fi you must read his books.  He's a very smart man and is very good at explaining things to non-physicists.

A real eye opener, even to those who are in the scientific world. It's an easy.  It changed my thinking on a lot of things and I see that we are only limited by our imaginations and Einstein's equation!
Really innovative insights specially on products that are currently in development, presents a bright future that transforms humanity into an innovative powerful race.
Excellent overview of trends for the future, often based on science and technology but written in a manner that everyone will readily comprehend.

I was mesmerise by Dr. Kaku's knowledge and his realistic view of our future!! I became his fan immidiatetly. Great Book! If everyone in the world read this book, the world would be a better place like in his prediction.
very interesting book.. he di drag it out a bit at the beginning but after that it was a fantastic book! i found it very easy to read.

Michio describes what life will be like in the next 100 years based on tech were coming out with now. This book is very interesting and covers everything from transportation, food, genetic manipulation, living in space, Home living, medical advances, holographic realities, Virtual life, and all sorts of cool upcoming Tech we can look forward to.

This awesome book looks at what changes science will bring us in the next 100 years and how that will shape humanity and our civilization as a whole.  If you want to tap into what our scientific community has been up to and is looking forward to you, this is a must read.  Highly Recommend this and all of the Michio Kaku books...learn something!

"Maybe" and "may" are words oftenly used in this admittedly inspiring work in which Dr. Kaku begins with the "actually happening" and continues with "possibilities".  As long as you can distinguish between the two, whose difference the good Dr. sometimes minimizes, perhaps unintentionally, you should be fine.

I bought two of these books after reading it myself.  One for my nephew who is off to college to show him all the possibilities of his chosen field (computers)  The second to a friend whose a rocket scientist.  Kaku takes complex ideas and technology and puts it into "wow" form that is easily understood.

After reading Brian Greene's Hidden Reality and struggling with the in-depth, high-minded material, it was very refreshing to read Kaku. His writing is charismatic and he makes complex topics easy to understand for us dummies. And the material is fascinating. Kaku is instantly my new favorite science writer.

The reason why I gave this book 3 stars, is because I thought – when I was reading the book – that the information was not very detailed about many subjects. The book contain a lot of different subjects who may can change the destiny (and our daily lives) of humans on our planet Earth.

This is one of the most fascinating books I have every read! I could not put it down. Mr. Kaku explains in clear simple language his vision of the future and he provides so much backup in all of his statements I'm sure he has an accurate handle on it. Read this book. You will love it!

Good introduction to cutting-edge technological advancements, but besides perhaps specific examples of research projects that Kaku has access to because of his credentials, there isn't much that you can't find in other publications, which think through the implications more deeply

I like the writting style, it brings difficult subjects into a place where it can be understood by all.  To know that everything in this book are based on experiments that aretaking place today is exciting,  the future in many areas look very bright and exciting.

Dr. Kaku reveals several different aspects of today's scientific achievements and possible future advancements that are easily understood for not only the sifi fan but scientists in all fields of study. I will certainly purchase other books authored by Dr. Kaku.

Love Michio Kaku! He has such a simple way of explaining the complex! I recommend all his books! This one is a great peek into the current and ongoing research into health, cars, computers, robots, etc. As Spock would say, "Fascinating!"

After I saw Professor Kaku on TV and found him to be easy to follow I read his informative books which are easy to read and understand.  I wish I had a teacher like that when I was in school - I would have enjoyed science and learned more then!

great book , but a bit out of date, since some things he describes as futuristic or currently under research are things we already take for granted - 3D printers, Facebook, cloud storage etc. the book was published in 2009 if i'm not mistaken.

This books is fascinating view into physics as it may already be, maybe one day be, or even a vent to one's imagination.  This book would  probably be enjoyed by one with an adventuresome mind whether one agrees with al aspects of it or not.

This book is well written and researched.  The style is easy to read by anyone and really holds your attention.  Love reading about all the new research and upcoming technology.  Definitely, makes me want to invest in the future.

Book quality was fine. Personally I find Kaku to be a little over the top but I bought it for a class so it's not like I had much of a choice but to read it. Definitely better than a lot of things my prof could have assigned.

A great insight of how Michio sees the development of technology changing our lives in the next 50-100 years. If you have a love for technology and have a wild imagination then I'm sure this will satisfying read.

I got this as a birthday gift for a friend.  As far as I know, he liked it.  I've read Physics of the Impossible & enjoyed. it.  Michio Kaku has a knack for putting things in layman terms.  He's very readable.

Another great book from Michio Kaku, gives you a real optimistic outlook on the future and physicists role in shaping our future, you can't help but fall in love with technology after reading this book.
Brilliant.  Michio Kaku has a lightness of penmanship and deep knowledge of the subject.  Since he is a physicist, his predictions do not violate any known laws of physics, therefore are possible.
Mr MK grabbed most of the available evolutionary research, explained the physics of law that supports them, and gave them meaning and motion for drawing  the future of humanity.  Great book!
My daughter loves Michio Kaku and is always seeking his futuristist and theoretical insight.  It almost fulfills a spiritual need for her. Always looking forward to more of his insight!
Outstanding analysis of the possible future.  First part of the book hard science, but slides into interesting speculation later on -- but speculation bu a very knowldegable scientist.
This was a group of books my son-n-law requested for his birthday.  They shipped quickly and in tack.  The freight was a little high but the book was used and in great condition
This was an excellent read. Suc a good read I sent it to an immunologist I had in graduate school at Edinboro University of Pa. Well written some parts tongue in cheek .
This book is a wonderful adventure to take as one reads. Reading Kaku's descriptions of what is quite possible for us as a world people is a positive and fun experience
This is so well written that even with the technical nature of the material, I found it quite comprehendable. I would recommend it for anyone interested in the future.
Loved this book by Kaku!  It was obvious all the research he put into the book.  I will have to keep it to see how close his predictions are to what actually happens!
This was my favorite read for 2012 and I am a voracious reader. Thought provoking and interesting from start to end. I gave a copy for gifts to both sons. Compelling!
As a non Quantum Physicist, Michio Kaku is a master is simplifying highly complex topics.  This is a must read!  It will open your eyes to the future of technology.
Heard about this on NPR. Writer, while brilliant, is able to communicate in easy, common sense language of the layman.  This is a great read for futurist thinkers.
This was presented in a very easy to understand but in-depth explanation.  Time travel was the most unique issue that is very hard to understand or comprehend.
I have not finished reading it. I will submit my final rating later!! So far it is pretty interesting. Dr. Kaku is a great Physics futurist and a good writer!
"From the oceans of knowledge to the Cosmos of philosophy , this book is journey through a new perspective to understand the Future of the Mankind"
I really like michio started by introducing each subject and then said what might happen in the near future, mid century and finally the end of the century
I bought this for my husband.  He's into this type of book.  He really loved it.  He has gotten other books by this author and really enjoys his works.
A long listen but great if you are into science.  Sometimes a bit technical but the author has interesting thoughts on how the future will be shaped.
One of the most thought stimulating books I have read  in a longtime. Well researched and written in a very "readable"  style. Excellent
Not yet finished reading it, but so far it's truly good. It's also intriguing to get an idea of the world awaiting my 2-year-old granddaughter.
I've been a science fiction fan all my life, but this is the real thing.  Our imagination seems to know no bounds, and it's  well written, too.
Dr. Kaku explains many complex scientific ideas in a clear and fascinating style, and presents believable forecasts of future development.
I am building a library about people and healing and things in the future so I thought this would be an excellent addition to my library.
A brilliant visionary.  Enjoyed the book.  Dr. Kaku is a very futuristic scientist. I enjoy his writing and look forward to future books.
Practical physics and predictions from one of the pre-eminent physicists of the day.  Another one you need to sit back and enjoy ride.
I'v read several of Michio Kaku's books before and I like them a lot since he writes so that the average person can understand  them.
Great read! The power of a mind like KAKU is remarkable. The future will be so interesting for our grandchildren as well as theirs.
Prof. Kaku's writing sometimes becomes a little bit sensational and he gets a few facts wrong. But a useful book nonetheless.
The book could have been 100 pages.  The same thing over and over. I read the first 75 pages, and skimmed the rest.  Sorry
I liked that he made the physics easy to understand. I would highly recommend this book. Audio version helped out as well
I loved this book ! Easy to read and so interesting! Michio Kaku writes for the Everyman and makes physics accessible fun
This product is exactly as advertised.  This product showed up on time and as advertised. I would recommend this product.
Fantastic book, with great concepts. Michio Kaku is a genius and I love reading his ideas. His whole series is great.
Another good book by Michio Kaku.  Many ideas to ponder for the future of technology and it's impacts on society.
this is a great book very interesting, easy to understand, I definitely recommend it now I am more in to science
While i felt that some of this might be purely fairy tale, all of it was fascinating. I couldn't put it down.
Interesting, hopefully some if the advances he talks about come to pass. Especially the medical advances.
Very intrigue with this product and the timely manner I received. Will purchase from this author again.
Love this author, his forward-thinking ideas backed by research and data. Great for an informal read.
I bought a copy of this book for my college aged daughter, to help guide her in her future plans.

Although the author does well discussing trends which some readers may not have heard about before, most of the book is too general and filled with simplistic arguments.  Also seems to be kind of anti-american, stating that "Americans benefit from immigrants from Asia who do not take our jobs."  Of course, Kaku is himself an immigrant to the US from Japan and he spends much of the book touting the accomplishments of Asia.  Perhaps a better title would be the "Future Discoveries of China and the Far East."
This is one of the most exciting non-fiction books I have ever read-- a real page-turner!
A fascinating and at times mind-boggling read. I recommend it for the average futurist.

I have never read a book by Professor Kaku prior and I must say after reading this book I am very interested in reading more literature from him. His style of writing and ability to convey science to the general public is what makes him so interesting and a powerful leader in the scientific community. I recommend this book to any one curious about what is currently being worked on and where that technology may take us in the future. Enjoy. -Joshua
A tour-de-force of science research and how it might affect our future.

I've read 3 other books by Micho Kaku and they all start out the same way with him explaining how he got interested in physics. I listen to and watch a lot of science programs and there's very little here that I haven't seen/herd before. I liked his earlier books much better. He really knows how to bring a very complicated subject down to a layman's understandable level. But this book is about predicting the future and we all know how unpredictable that is (the Jetsons come to mind). They have been working on robots for decades that the common man could use and so far the best they have come up with is a relatively useless vacuum cleaner and a automated drink serving tray. We all want that robot that will do what the Jetsons robot could do. About five years ago I heard about a collage student that was trying to invent just a robotic dish washer that could deal with the dirty dishes from picking up the dirty dishes, scraping off the food, scrubbing the hard food off, washing and drying and putting them away. But so far I haven't herd anything successful in that project. It's just to complicated for a computer to tell the difference between the dirt on the dish or a printed pattern. That's because computers don't have the ability to understand anything and I don't believe they ever will. Even those cars that can drive them selves only react to censer input. The computer driving the car has no understanding like humans do as to what it's doing. He even predicts our doctor in the future will be an interaction with a computer. While I think that's possible I don't think the doctor's union (medical association) would go for that. To much money involed and would you really trust your health to a health diagnostic devise that's similar to our GPS devices. Anybody that has used GPS extensively knows it makes mistakes (like telling you to turn left onto a road that isn't there) I would like to see Dr Kaku write a book about all the work and successes that physicist's out side of the theoretical physics world have done. We the average Joe know little about there contributions to new and recent developments in such topics as new materials that have been developed like batteries that can be  made into any shape. But as with his Science Channel program SciFi Science Dr Kaku seems to be heading down the same road as the programing that has overtaken the Discovery channel designed to appeal to the beer guzzling, dumb ass segment of our society, or children under 16 years old.
Great read for anyone interested in what the future may hold.
Interesting book. So says the person I bought it for anyway.
Nothing new but as always by Mr. Kaku well-written.

This is a great gift.  I bought for myself, my parents, my children, and I will get more for people I care about.  It can make children think science is cool and care more about new subjects. It is a gift to know what the future may bring.
His presentation wants you to read more.
It was a wonderful gift for my brother.
enjoyed it, good read very informative.
already out of date as of early 2015
My son really likes this book.

This book is a quick overview of many possible future technologies.  It's very much like his discovery channel show: long on wonder, short on details.  If you've never head of the technologies he's talking about, it might be a good primer.  But I'd imagine most people who are looking for a book like this are singularity types and will find it lacking.

I have read almost all of Michio Kaku's books and in my opinion "Physics of the Future" is one of his best. Why do I think so? Because Michio Kaku was able to cover so many subjects in only a few hundred pages. His style is clear, synthetic and passionate. I also believe that it is a very important book, because it shows in a simple and entertaining way the importance of science, especially in an era where many young people are still ignorant or unaware of  the many challenges that face our civilization in the future.
It was way over my head

I have seen Kaku on tv numerous times on the Science Channel. Intelligent guy! But this book and his idea of the future is frightening. He has many themes on which he speaks. Growing body parts, creating life and the human android. Immortality and on, on, on. Only a fool would want to live forever. And the thought of losing what makes us human, ourselves, is in my opinion, Balderdash! If you desire immortality and want to live on barren planets to exist, you have my blessing. Otherwise, keep science and the desire for all knowing immortality out of my personal space. All these science types want is control and dependence on themselves. As far as recreating dinosaurs, why? Could not control them millions of years ago and won't be able to now. Stupidity!! I'm 74 years old and would not change a damned thing, and, will leave on my own terms at three score and ten, plus!
You should reed it

This is the motherload of geekiness. Physicist Michio Kaku writes a very fun, very very interesting look at what the future of the next 100 years will hold for our species. The difference from this one and other futurists is that Kaku is an actual scientist who is seeing the technological revolution happen from the inside. He covers all sorts of topics from the future of computers, AI, medicine, energy and space travel. This is a truly enjoyable book and I recommend it to anybody with at least a passive interest in science. I will try to read the other books by Michio Kaku.
Good Product .

This is the best compiled estimation of what future events will look like due to the advancements in technology and current research.  I have given this book to my children and grandchildren as to what they can expect in their lifetime and beyond.  Michio Kaku has summarized human knowledge of physics and current research in many fields and estimastes how far technology will change our human enviornment.  This is one of the most important books written about what lies ahead for our society.
mind blown
great,fast

If you're thinking that you're gonna put the CD version of this on your iPod, I've got some bad news. There is no entry in the Gracenote database for this 13 CD audiobook. I don't understand why, in the 21st century, an audiobook gets released without it's track info being already uploaded to Gracenote. Frustrating.

Very interesting - and scary.  Doesn't seem like we'll have any privacy in the future.  Well written and easy to read and understand. BUT - I think I am glad that I won't be around - unless I'm well over 100 years old!

Got this book for my husband.  He loves it, as he's all about science.  He shares some of the book's info with me - almost inconceivable for someone like myself who a concrete visualist.  So interesting...
Its difficult sometimes to see the future and its likely life experiences but this book focuses on technology and its likely development tracks rather than changing human experiences.
Good book to pick up....read a couple chapters....think about the concepts....set down...pick up again in a couple weeks and read some more. Son, husband, and mom reading it too.
Very informative,full of facts,as expected.Saw the interview with author on The Colbert Show,god the book.Well written! Your teenagers can read it to!
I still did not read the whole book but so far I am satisfied. Never heard before about the author but he seems to know what he's talking about.
I do like the book although predicting the future is not what I try to do in my life.  Perhaps for those in computers it makes more sense.
if you are in the science and technology and want to know what is next, I recommend you to try this book.  You are going to have fun.
I really enjoyed the book, it offers from the perspective of Michio Kaku how the world wil look in 100 years, I strongly recommend it
Everybody should read this scientific preview. A lot of this preview is coming soon and maybe even faster if the economy improves.
This is a thrilling ride on an imaginary trail of technology explosions in the future probably beyond the lifespan of most of us.
One of the best books you will read in a long while. Michio Kaku is the Albert Einstein of our generation. Just a brilliant book.
Kaku really makes me wish I was born 30 years later... gets you excited and optimistic about the future of the human civilization
This book is a must read for those who might want to glimpse into the future of physics. Very informative and easy to read.
I only hope I live long enough to see some of these predictions materialize; especially the one about living forever.
Excellent book on a difficult topic. Micho Kaku is the Carl Sagan of the 21'st century, would recommend this book.
This can have a great impact on how I view my business and where we need to go.  Mankind is in for a wild ride
Simply amazing. The man is a genius !!! I recommend for anyone with an open mind and loves to read
He really knows his stuff.  A Harvard grad with both feet on the ground.  rare.

A great book with plenty of interesting information.  I've seen other reviews (one in the NT Times, I believe) that accused the author of having an otherworldly writing style - I did not find that to be the case.  The first day I had this book, I read over 100 pages!  Very satisfied!
A good scientific approach at predicting future technological advancements.
the voice actor in this is kind of s***ty but the book is amazing.
the Author makes it easy to paint the picture of the story

Everyone should read this book.  Wonderfully informative.
Great book.  Well written.  Very hard to put down.

The audio book is awesome . My husband loved it
It was a wonderful gift for my daughter.
Some what repetitive, but interesting.
Well presented and very readable!

Extremely interesting!!!!!
very interesting indeed.

Don't expect any details on the exciting possibilities presented by Kaku. It's a light read, perfect for the everyday layman who is wondering what the future may be like. However, when Dr. Kaku ventures out into geopolitics things can get a little muddy. Particularly, his views into "Islamic terrorism" are horribly simplistic. Kaku avoids getting into the reasons behind the existence of terrorism, and takes the easy route into the "they hate us for our freedoms" la-la-land. Perhaps the major letdown in the book was finding a quote by the loathsome Thomas Friedman towards the end of the book. Kaku is smart enough to be able to prove a point without quoting that odious gasbag.
so so..that's all...
Excellent condition

Very interesting
my son love it
Great book!

I am two chapters in, and it seems pretty interesting.  its hard to predict the next 90 years, but he gives great reasoning as to why certain things will or will not come to fruition .  he is very knowledgeable  on our (humans) technological abilities in many areas.
thanks
I loved this book. It really made me imagine and wonder what the future will have to bring. I want to see technologies grow and someday become something that we had never imagined.
ok
very monotonous

Dr Kaku presents the material in such a way that even the non scientific community can enjoy. He is very realistic in his predictions referencing the current technologies that are in development today and also stating the possible shortcomings of them.  All in all a great read.

I think the total value of the Bible (or other religious books) in 2011 can be summarized by the commonly known phrase "Do unto others as you'd have them do unto you", and I also think Dr. Kaku's new book has the potential to be the guidebook for a new generation of the world's masses.  When considering the overriding theme of this book that Dr. Kaku consistently proves that scientific progress has invariably led to improved living conditions for humanity in all ways (albeit with some unfortunate consequences at times), it seems to me that this book should become as ubiquitous and important to the human race as the Bible (Quran, etc, etc) has been for the past two thousand years.  If the turnout for his book tour across the country is any indication (sold out shows), a younger generation that sees things more clearly than its forebears could well make that happen and it would be of huge benefit to our world.

JPS "JPS" (Cincinnati, OH) said it best. I would simply add that I think this is, however,  a great read for high school level. The writing is Young Adult level and therefore a bit too simplistic for my taste. For a true science junkie, this is rather thin stuff.
Girlfriend loved it. Says its great. While much of the high level physics is left out, that's exactly what we were looking for. Thanks Michio!
Awesome book, clear, easy to read and very exiting. Prof. Kaku is the best physics speecher now a days. 100% recommended.

I happen to highly respect the author as a rarity in science; someone who can relate difficult ideas and concepts to someone like myself, who is not well versed in the left part of my mind. Parts of this book are mind blowing, particularly when discussing the possibilities of future space travel. Unfortunately, he allows his politics to largely skew the entire book. For example, he keeps referring to the ipcc when discussing global warming, and continues to cite their predictions at the end of the book. However, he completely ignores the fraudulent practices from the scientists of east Anglia, England, often referred to as "climate gate". In short, much of the "data" was fudged.... As a scientist, you would think to at least mention this rather than citing fudged data as fact simply to suit your political beliefs. He also assumes that nation states will weaken, citing the European union as an example... Ignoring the glaring fact that the eu is collapsing as we speak, and that most people are not too thrilled to have their sovereignty taken away. In short, I still highly respect him as a relatable and personal science, but please shut up about your politics... Or in the very least, be more open about how your personal biases are influencing your predictions,

We are avid readers. I cannot critique every book we buy. Suffice it to say that the majority of the books we buy meet our criteria for what ever it is we expect from the particular one we have purchased. I don't remember there being any books we weren't satisfied with.

I like Kaku, but this book is not for me.  I read the first two chapters and put it back on my book shelf.  If you want to learn science get a science book like Kaku's "Parallel Worlds" or "Hyperspace".

The subtext of this book is, "How science will shape human destiny and our daily lives by the year 2100".  The author gets an F-.  He takes no account of the relationship between the science and study of physics . . . to political and social realities.  Talks about "advances" from an elitist-science-nerd and pollyanna point of view.  Ends with a Disney world ride into space as an advance and accomplishment of science.  Space bases on the Moon and 3 billion on earth with malaria.  This book is an absolute no-no for school children.  Has nothing to do with the needs and lives of a  vast majority of real people.  Builds on the unproven concept that advances in technology will automatically bring wealth to a larger portion of the world's population and that education will allow the voting population to make more rational decisions.  Neglects the effects of advances in technology increasing the possibility of more destructive wars and destabilizing world order.

I don't get it. I am 33% through the book and he is re-educating me on things I already know, about cancer, its history and the Moore's theory and there is no physics stuff or anything really interesting so far.  Just about how robots will be part of the future and the insane notion that they will become smarter than humans and take over. Yea right, until humans turn them off. Not worth reading if you are truly interested in physics.

Ungrounded "pedal to the metal" "silver bullet" technology arrogantly further separating ourselves from ourselves/creation is just more of the same madness that has gotten us to the brink of self destruction.  Ridiculous and sad.....

This book was recommended to me by a very friend who said I would not be disappointed with the book.  He was right.  The book gives you a good sense of progress that is being made in medicine and other technological fields.
Michio Kaku presents the future too use in an optimistic and hopeful way. It does tend too get a little redundant but in the long run I enjoyed this book. Its a matter of preference.

This is yet another rehash of the information covered in any number of popular science magazines, such as Discover.  Just as with "Physics of the Impossible" Kaku offers little if anything new in this book.
I read the first chapter and gave up. The writing reads like a bad author from 1985 fantasizing about the year 2000. I didn't see anything having to do with physics in there, either.
His understanding of the H1B visa is entirely wrong. Go to youtube and search for "Dan Rather Reports - No Thanks for Everything" if you want to know the truth about the H1B visa.

Based on his repeated statements of the obvious, both in his television appearances and his writings, I would pass on this book. Better to spend your time studying the latest on the theory of everything and come to your own conclusions of the future. I think this guy has made enough money.
very disappointing.  i read two other books by this author and this book seemed like a repeat of earlier work.
The book was going along very well until Dr. Kaku introduced his unbounded enthusiasm for President Obama into his book.  At that point I quit reading, and will not read any more of his books.

I was very disapointed with Physics of the Future because it is written for people with an IQ of 100 and lower. Dr. Kaku is so much smarter than this book. I cannot believe that he has so lack of vision. He believes that Moores Law will slow down or stop. I wonder if he has ever read a great book The Singularity is Near. Moores Law is a narrow focus on computer technology and Ray Kurzweil, who is a visionary teaches about The Law of accelerating returns that is much larger in scope and has to do with the exponential acceleration of information in evolution technology. I admire Ray for writing a book that is intelligent and does not dumb down to the reader. Michio does not understand his readers and wants to cater to the general public and I found this book insulting in something to read that is intelligent.
This bimbo kaku is completely out of touch with the latest developments in science.  He needs to go back to school and get himself a decent education.

I love to read physics books and thought this book might be interesting.  What a disappointment!  It is just a sermon on outlandish ideas wrapped up in atheistic mumbo jumbo with an extreme socialistic background.  Not only does he constantly degrade God and praise "Mother Nature" but he obviously believes man is his own God.  But the final bit of nonsense is his later chapters on Economics and Capitalism.  He preaches the absurd Marxist viewpoint on all political issues.  I still would like to know what that gibberish has to do with physics.  This book is just a monologue on the beliefs of an atheistic, left-wing  extremist.  If that is your take on life be a masochist and read it.  If you want to learn more about physics get another book.
